review_title: Cutting Edge.  Industry bellwether. Employee Centric.
pros:
Working at SAP gives me a sense of pride. When you walk into a meeting with a customer, you are looked at not as a software provider but as an advisor to the business. This is because the offerings that SAP brings to its customers are often the market defining products. So we have a direct influence in shaping the markets that we operate in. 

Having worked in the software industry for the last 15 years, I can say that it’s not just the products of SAP but also the employee policies here that are a topic of envy. And this is not just related to the remuneration. SAP takes a genuine effort in its employee well-being through a host of engagements. Right from day one you get the feeling that you are part of a large family and it creates a true sense of belongingness and camaraderie. SAP is quick to adopt and very often at the forefront in defining employee policies that are in step with the changing dynamics of the workforce. 

From a career progression standpoint, the worldwide presence of SAP and the comprehensive portfolio of products, made it possible for me to explore multi-disciplinary and multi-region career options. Overall the combination of a market leading product with a truly employee centric philosophy is what makes the SAP culture stand out on its own.
cons: Reacting to a dynamic market requires constant changes in strategy and in an organization the size of SAP this becomes a change management challenge. Even with the best efforts in ensuring smooth transitions over key changes, one has to be prepared to deal with team rejigs, role changes, portfolio reassignments etc.

pros:
- Perfect work life balance
- Amount of stress and work is just right for a 9-5 role, rarely have to clock extra hours to complete work
- Great culture - frequent get togethers outside of work, non toxic environment, politics and mistrust is not tolerated. 
- Outstanding leadership, a lot of emphasis on trust and strong leadership to grow and develop employees
- Thousands of learning courses available at no cost for self development
- Growth opportunities with yearly reviews and increments based on performance.
cons:
- Processes are antiquated and have not been updated in probably a decade or 2, creating a lot of inefficiency and long, drawn out admin work.
- While it is pivoting to a more customer centric org, it used to be a very old school 'sales organisation' with processes setup to benefit mainly sales reps. These processes still exist so it can end up being a tug of war with the sales team. The processes also enables the sales team to go rogue at the expense of other teams.
- HR processes needs improvement.
- A small thing, but the office location in Singapore is at MBC, which is not very central.

pros:
SAP is a technology company that has a Human Centered approach towards its employees, customers and interactions. Understanding that our people are our best assets to pivoting ourselves forward in our connected world.
Our focus is truly our people, diversity, pride and inclusion being part or our genetic make up. Our people every year compete amongst ourselves to create a model, platform or marketable idea that can impact 1 Billion lives through positive economic or social impact, why wouldn't you be proud to be part of that positive social movement.

We also don’t do a great job in retaining good talent and hr rarely practices what they preach and can often turn a blind eye to real issues individual employees surface.

pros:
based on merit. this company definitely promotes internal hiring first. Although there is a current hiring freeze within the company, no team member has been let go in lieu of the COVID-19 pandemic. Roles are still available and open to internal hires. 
Staff have been advised to WFH entirely but the office remains open for those who wants to break the monotony of WFH (standard social distancing and masking measures are in place).
This is a company that shows trust in its most important resource - people.
Employee benefits remain very very competitive in this industry. On-boarding process established and stable, expect a smooth experience for first day. Equipment, credentials, passes, would have all been made ready prior.

contracting process may be complex for customers; this means the internal process can be daunting to new folks.

job_title: Senior Human Resources Consultant in Singapore
pros:
SAP promotes work life balance to jagger between job and family. Besides, also providing employees with almost the best benefits coverage on medical, well-being and career advancement opportunities. Apart from working hard, we play hard as well with monthly engagement events roll out. 

SAP practice diversity & inclusion by given a fair and equal employment opportunity as well as providing advice and coaching on career developments. Apart from having the flexibility working arrangement, employee is able to work from home as well.

Clean and spacious working environment with accessibility to pantry, nursing room, game area, nap pod, lockers etc (just to name a few).
cons: Unfortunately none that I could share.

pros:
Great benefit and health insurance.
Great middle level manager (at least mine is)
Work-life balance
Got interesting products, the latest technologies to work on.
Culture is friendly, warm.
Actively engage employees.
The company is steering to the right innovation direction.
Nice, smart colleagues.
Very stable.
cons:
I love this company, but it's not without its problems. Hopefully, someone can read this and help to improve SAP.
1, Politics is prevalent. Favoritism is popular.
2, Seniority still favors over meritocracy.
3, Discrimination is pretty prevalent. There is a big difference in treatment between German/White/Germany-office employees and  all others: 
- Same job but German/white people always got higher titles even they are hired at the same time, in the same department and doing the same things. It applies to everyone in my department. Needless to say to salary will be different.
- Slow promotion for non-German/non-white employees.
- A number of people just got promoted to managers because they are German. I know a few German managers who are doing very little, know literally nothing about the field they're managing, always on vacation but still got promoted quickly to director and VP. It's so crazy. 
Germans employees sometimes are pretty arrogant and don't value the opinions of their colleagues.
The above reason also makes the product is uncompetitive because the weak managers who oversee the products have little knowledge in the relevant fields.
4, Heavy processes which really slows down the innovation.
5, Inadequate equipment. E.g.: impossible to request for 2 monitors.

pros:
1. I was involved in a production project as like full time employees, thus I got real industrial experience. I guessed this was the best benefit: to learn from them how a software project should progress in a structured way.
At the same time, I was taken good care of as an intern, with no heavy work load.
2. I was encouraged to tried different project or different aspects of project as I want. Thus, you could try and learn different things, as long as you want to.
3. We had knowledge sharing sessions every two weeks, which helps us get exposed to innovated technologies.
4. The working hours are free. You just need to make sure you finish your task.
cons: I felt everything was perfect, at least as an intern. I didn't know much about what full-time employees think of SAP. So maybe only take my words into consideration if you are an intern.

pros:

cons:
- Recruitment are not the core focus of the company, it's easier to enter SAP than entering Harvard or Google. Culture shifts, and hiring manager has way too much power in selecting the candidates they want, instead of mandating opinions from people with no-bias to the candidate or people around working with them
- Culture is shifting, the vision from global are not well understood in asia

review_title: Excellent employer. You can go fast or slow, climb the ladder or stay comfortable.
pros: Great fringe benefits - marriage bonus, baby bonus, good medical & insurance, great annual bonus, loads of learning opportunities (products & soft skills), phone & internet bill; some colleagues even have company cars; many travel and relocation opportunities. Excellent work-life balance. Pregnant and women who have babies may arrange to work at home some days
cons: too much space also means you have to seek and grab the chances yourself. Sometimes you can be left on the cold stone for months when what you are doing isn't needed any more or sponsored... on-boarding was not very well organized and it can be overwhelming for new comers. Took me (and some of my colleagues) 6-12 months to figure out what system does what, what product names etc.

review_title: Young Manager Wannabees, do not look here..
pros:
A diversified workplace where people work and play hard. 
A few sections within SAP are protected enclaves which provides job security and proper work-life balance.
cons:
Changes at the management level recently have caused an overhaul and the politics have trickled down to the "masses"
Also, try navigating your way through the myraid of people who are working on the same thing as you and then fight for your share of the pie.
There are basically too many people to go round, too little work to do.
And career hungry junior level employees need to be extremely patient, allowing yourself to age and grow old within the company before getting anywhere as the majority of the senior employees will more or less starve you of any opportunity to proceed further.

pros: Definitely the people - you can always  count on your team to come back to something when needed, rally around, help any time you need it. Good benefits. Good working hours. Flexible management style, trust and cooperation, very diverse environment.  Working hard on diversity and inclusion. Leadership I find are inclusive of younger and different genders overall.
cons: Not always simple to navigate, which I suppose is the nature of a very large, international company. But doesn't always run simple. Many processes and long periods to get things done. Channels and sales could enjoy better collaboration (which is undoubtedly the same for all organisations).  Not as relaxed in terms of dress code in my view as it could be; still quite formal and 'office style' especially for women.  As other companies like Google and start up businesses relax their style maybe SAP could try that too.

pros:
Besides your routine job scope, my employers got me actively engaged in different  projects to improve the business and processes.
Employers were opened to ideas and will further provide inputs and fine tune the projects to achieve greater results.
Coaching session was provided by my VP to further strengthen my personal character understanding and development.
My remuneration package was very competitive. Work from home is not an issue as long as work are delivered and it does not clash with any meetings or appointments.
cons:
Tendency to keep poor attitude or low performing people. Office politics is very real which hinder progression and betterment of the company.
Recent retrenchment was done at the HQ level without understanding the roles that they are eliminating, causing major disruption to those who survive the cut.
Top management and HQ seems to lack real understanding of what is happening within their own company.

review_title: Sounds good on the outside, rotten internally
pros: Great brand name, produces a very high quality product,  industry leader, pay and bens top 2 quartiles against similar companies, great for the CV.
cons: Very Germanic culture - spreadsheets and death by powerpoint are the language, little entrusted to employees, cannot use your initiative, almost no career path or ongoing learning/development programmes, almost no feedback on job performance, good or bad. Top management is mostly recruited in from outside at high salaries with few internal promotions, little diversity - few if any women, minorities in positions of management, no transparency in communication and late communication when the rumour mill has been running until management figures out how to do PR messages, people are a commodity and not valued, HR very weak and does not work for employees at all. Toxic and highly political environment, especially in marketing department.

review_title: The blue-chip of the blue-chips but German culture is not for everyone.
pros: As the blue-chip of the blue-chip software vendors one should endeavor to go through SAP's doors at least once in your career.  Does good things for your CV.
cons:
Germany culture is not for everyone.  Definitely the anti-thesis of American style culture companies.
The breadth of the solution is so huge unless you have prior experience working on any of their products newbies get overwhelmed very quickly.  It may take more than a year to be acquainted sufficiently to perform the role of a sales consultant to customer.  That's the reason why a lot of people scrape by in SAP and don't earn the respect of the SAP folks internally.  There's a lot of newbies and old folks in the company but the middle is bare!

pros: SAP brand still has the ability to attract some really good talents and company has shown some great innovation
cons: Poor efforts in retaining and developing talent. Old school German top down culture. Information flows slowly as it trickles down the ranks. Middle managers abusing their position of power to take credit for teams' work and performance, senior managers ignorant of the fact, and executive management too high up to even care to listen to the lower ranks.

pros:
Nice looking office with nespresso machines,free fruit and soft drinks.
Decent working hours.
cons:
Singaporeans usually have to start on 6 month contract under an outsourcing company's payroll. As such you have rather poor benefits. Some staff have been on rolling 6 month contracts and have not been converted to permanent status. Incidentally Singaporeans seem to be a minority in the organisation.
Very lean organisation. Company does not have a typical hierarchy e.g. you do not have junior and senior staff on a team, no team leaders, assistant managers or managers. It's usually a team of one (at least for non-developer positions) and the first level supervisor is at least a director. As such there isn't really anyone who can show you the ropes. I feel like your experience may vary significantly depending on your boss.
Staff seem isolated and working on their own things. Did not get a feeling of a collaborative environment.

pros:
- Great compensation
- Work from home opportunities
- Good benefits
- Manageable workload
cons:
- Too much process (difficult to create change)
- A bit old school. Ambitious individuals will struggle here as you must "pay your dues" and fast advancement is not typical
- Can be challenging to work here as a Millenial

pros: Having a positive impact on governments, the commercial sector and people consuming SAP products overall from line of business users, services consumers to sports fans. Incredibly fast paced company with what one would consider a strong backbone developed over four decades of enthusiastic, motivated people with the highest customer focus, integrity and professionalism. It's a fun place to be.
cons: You have to actively develop your own career at SAP; the good and bad thing is enterprise business technology is changing so fast that there is so many opportunities coming up constantly but because it's changing so fast it's in the personal interest of the employee to drive the career more actively than in other slower moving industries/ companies/ peer companies.

review_title: Large software company with fantastic benfits

-Great place to work - great work/life balance, as many roles can be done virtually.
cons:
- It takes time to hit the ground running, to learn the policies and procedures of such a large company
Like many public companies, cost containment is always top of mind. Generally toward the end of the year, travel becomes restricted, etc

cons: Promotion is not based on meritocracy but rather who you know. Common for leaders to fill positions with people of their own nationalities rather than capabilities.  Lots of mess and non-value added work due to an amazing pool of incapable leaders  around smoking their ways through. Bullying culture exists and only the top management have direct access to HR, the rest are processed by log tickets or who you know.

review_title: Great Place Slipping Down the Drain
pros:

Multi Cultural Environment
cons:

Unfair treatment of employees after cost cutting measures were put in place; for example reduction of travel and mobility is not applied commonly across the board
Company is struggling with new board members, strategy is not clear and those who performed well before are being kicked-out
Having to deal with colleagues in the US who think they are the center of the world

pros:
Great work-life balance. 
Inclusive and diverse company. 
Competitive salary and benefits. 
They are interested to help you grow in your career. I remember that in my first week, not only I had to plan my role OKRs, but I had to plan out my career development plan with my manager and had strategize on what are the tools and resources I can tap on within SAP to achieve my career goals.
cons: Like every other big MNC, it's tough initially to wrap your head around on how to navigate the internal ecosystem with its multiple business units.

pros: People are generally nice. Doesn't give me the dog eat dog or pretentious vibes I get from other tech companies. Good onboarding for new employees. A lot of e-learning to help you get up to speed and improve yourself! Lots of people who have stayed more than a decade, so something must be going right. Industry leading solutions in many categories.
cons: It's a mega big organisation with a lot of products and solutions. It's not easy to get up to speed and people have told me it's impossible to know everything that SAP have to offer.

pros:
Work-life balance is encouraged.

Employees seem to be treated well, respected and everyone has a voice. They are also expected to take control of their own careers. No hand-holding here unless absolutely necessary.

The ability to work from home is amazing and this notion seems to constant throughout the company.

Compensation seems to be fair.

Most people seem very nice, this seems to be a constant at all levels from junior, experience, senior and management staff. There is a certain level of warmth and friendliness through the company. This is encouraging as there seems to be a high level of collaboration, non-combative behaviour and generally, there is a an emphasis being team players and always aiming for a win-win scenario in everything.

The office and work environment are nice, with good facilities, recreational areas and well-equipped desk although I'm not personally a fan of the open office concept but I understand it is simply how the office is arranged.

Generally and broadly speaking, everyone I've encountered seems to be incredibly skilled at their jobs. This is a positive thing as this hopefully means that there is plenty of room of competent people and little room for freeloaders or incompetent people.

Work is fun and challenging (for me at least).

The culture is fantastic so far. The reviews, comments, and opinions of SAP as a company has indeed been very true. It is indeed a great place to work.
cons:
The company is huge with numerous departments. Navigating around every aspect is incredibly intimidating and potentially difficult to understand easily. 

There is a huge learning curve in understanding the core concept of the company (SAP is broadly a software company but it's also so much more) and there are many, almost too numerous products to understand.

The ability to take charge of one's own career is both a pro and a con as new hires can get lost without guidance from their managers.

pros: No Pros as of now

I left my very stable job and joined SAP which gave me surprise with 5 months of joining. And they project like they are providing internal opportunities, but these are all just for show off. The internal interviews were way tougher than interviews they take for external candidates. Please think twice before joining these kind of companies.

review_title: They know how to hype themselves
pros: Decent salaries, good customers, all the benefits of a large company
cons: Too much bureaucracy, too many legacy managers who bring nothing to the business, too many constraints to paying good employees properly -- you're locked into the salary you were hired into, with a small indexation to the cost of living. Newer employees with less experience are often paid the same rate as you, or more. There is little consistency in pay grades over comparable work. Also, this company finally learned in recent years to work the Glassdoor system and make sure they get positive reviews. The internal talk is not at all as positive as what you see here.

job_title: Account Executive in Le Havre, Normandy
pros: SAP is one of the biggest/greatest names in technology. You will work with some of the brightest people you’ve ever met who are really good at their job. Unlimited resources and the ability to make a lot of money. Industry leader in a lot of products.
cons: A micro management environment which stems from the top down. This is not all of SAP but more so in the mid market. Less empowered to think for yourself as they’ve started hiring folks with less experience as they are more likely to follow the straight line approach without question. The role has really moved to an inside beginners sales role. Leaders will strong arm their way into your deals rather than train you to be a better rep.

review_title: You learn a lot but they pay really low
pros: -You learn a lot, they make you do the work of full-time employees so you know how it works in real-life. You get trained. -Colleagues are friendly and supporting. -Working students have the opportunity to jump from one department to another department easily compared with full time employees needing to sign up for a fellowship.
cons: -Very very low salary despite doing a developer related job.. -Got an SAP appreciate award, the award giver wants to give me a monetary token, manager said it is not possible because the award might be taken advantage of (but SAP website clearly says I can receive it). Like a poorly paid working student will take advantage of the award? That few euros would lessen and help the impact of inflation especially you pay super low, you know?

review_title: Great people and culture but BYO innovation
pros: Wonderful colleagues, great solutions and customers, great culture and DEI, nice benefits and pay, good career trajectory. Remote roles and work is the norm. Many career opportunities exist since this is a 100K org.
cons: Even with an internal cloud transformation underway martech and CRM systems and processes lag and aren’t cutting edge - ‘the cobbler’s children never wear shoes’. Processes can be daunting and like any large org things take ages for funding, approval, and access. From my perspective all the tech innovation goes to customers. You’d better bring your own innovation, force your team to experiment with tech and new marketing, or outsource with agencies because you won’t learn modern marketing at SAP.

pros: I was part of the North America layoffs for SAP. I don't feel all too bad, because I thought SAP was rather courteous about it - given the recent news of other companies' layoffs, I got a message ahead of time, a month of sort-of not-really "employment" (to look for another role in the company, if possible), and general help with my sort-of not-really "unemployment". I mention all this because SAP, and I, prided the company's "family" values. It did seem the company cared about the employees. During the pandemic and after there wasn't a point where my arm was twisted and I was forced to do so-and-so. My team and I worked at our own pace and took the breaks we needed for our mental health - and we worked better for it. While I considered other opportunities in the past, this culture really stuck out to me and I felt this would have been rare in other companies. All the compensation in the word really doesn't touch upon this.
cons: That being said, I was bitter over not being bitter. I had been re-assigned to a different project last year and it was intolerably difficult to affect any change. There is a prevalent sense the company should be Agile, but no one, with any influence, was willing to criticize very slow, essentially Waterfall practices. My team and other teams were re-assigned but we had little training and were given few tasks to do; it would take several months to actually get features - fairly small in anyone's definition - shipped. New projects would be planned and talent would not be assigned. It was a huge waste of resources. Meanwhile, our competitors were soldiering ahead. In this environment, one inevitably thinks about their own career. This hurt because I like the company. I understand Rome wasn't built in a day. And, with Scrum, it's not about blaming anyone. But that's my honest opinion. My hope is that other domains in SAP take the actions to be and remain competitive.

review_title: Great culture working with diverse Teams
pros: - Great culture! - Team members from all over the world which I find exciting - Great support from team members and colleagues - Good working climate - Hybrid working and flexible work time with much flexibility - Understanding and support for me as a parent, part time work is possible - Bonus is reliable within a defined range - Focus on fair pay and equal pay; pay is ok (not top top level, but upper mid range) - work-live balance is manageable due to flexibility - Job comes with safety, it is a company you can stay for a longer time and develop within, if you wish - ESSP (buy stocks with getting some on top) is exceptional compared to other companies - free lunch, which is nice
cons: - Additonal Bonuses are available but rare compared to other companies I know - Bonus is reliable (it will never be zero) but it can not be significant high, like double - Salary is not top top level (but culture, team, jobs tasks, development opportunities ... all together it compensates ) - benefits from other companies provide more overall, like more budget for a company car, spending budget for health etc

pros: -Flexible work schedule -Treats you like an adult -Allows you to run your territory without micro management -Great benefits -Family first - always supports you if you have family matters come up -Pays well -PTO is great -DEI is apart of the corporate DNA and they take that seriously -Fun working environment -Remote - there is an office in most cities that you can work at if you want too, but you can also work from home. You get to choose when you travel and can customize your schedule as needed -No such thing as "work life balance" - what I mean by that is they are so flexible that its very much so get your work done however that looks for you. That way if you need to pick kids up from school, go to the doctor, etc do it, and then work when you can! This is the BEST feeling. No stress or anxiety of needing to take care of basic life needs. -Some of the best employees! Everyone is willing to help where they can - I have yet to have someone push something off on me, or be unsupportive. The staff at SAP is a tenure staff and have been doing this a long time, therefore they are so knowledgeable and willing to support newer employees.
cons: -A lot of information to learn and your job is relevant on how much you know -Training is great but its a data dump - make sure you take good notes -There is a lot of internal coordination - you have endless resources which sounds amazing but you need to know what resource and when to engage them. You will play a lot of "musical calendars" -Organization!!!! If you are not organized this job can take a toll on you - you are the owner of your account and its your responsibility to do everything for that account from scheduling meetings to taking care of administrative work

review_title: A lot of Lip service, but you get out of it what you put in
pros: Company's approach to "Hybrid" and Flex means you are expected to show a face, to collaborate, be a Team player. But on individual basis it seems some come in a lot less than once per week. The new renovated Flex Spaces are very nice... but "team collaboration" almost means not time for work, but time for socialising and play time at the games corner. We are well able to collaborate and deliver 120% for the past 2 years. (stopping here before turning a good thing into a Negative) Good health/dental/vision cover/Pension/ company share options. But then what Tech company at this level doesn't provide these "competitive" incentives? There are also some "restricted stock units"... probably a Plus. But that's why they are nicknamed Golden Handcuffs I should end this with some positives... Lots of Diversity and Inclusion (&I) and Women's Business support, mental health talks and virtual workshop with VHI... and some volunteering opportunities - though most are too busy with work to make use of their 2 days' volunteering per year. A great place to work for those new to IT Professional services, consulting, and technology pre-sales.
cons: Like any big corporate environment, you will find disconnect from the upper management with the grunts. Middle managers have a variety from the super helpful and fostering growth to be the best on their Team, to the absolute nutters who only chase after KPIs like robots are their underlings (probably OK mindset to have in times of War). Not everyone is a team player, and even though the company pushes for "bridges not silos", some people are only Take and Take. God help us if they reach Lead/Management levels. Salary is not as high as it should b e for a Dublin role. No cash incentive to set up home office throughout COVID pandemic. Office chairs/old monitors were offered, but these are still company property and once people returned to office, these had to be returned. Internal bonus cash incentives have been massively trimmed/negated. So don't be expecting thanks for going above and beyond for anyone else (not that "keeping count" is healthy anyways), it was nice having upwards of a thousand in cash to spend come Christmas for all the extra time put into helping colleagues outside of normal work endeavours. The huge change in leadership and exec rosters in the past 5 years have left many demoralised. And we have never quite recovered after Bill left (TBH). Though, Irish senior management seem to be on the ball about the Local situation and do follow up on some topics when brought up constantly over the 2-3 years. Experienced colleagues are being poached by competitors like it is 2008 again.

review_title: Can be good or bad depending on what you're willing to put up with or your stage in life
job_title: Senior Service Delivery Manager in Galway
pros: - Great benefits (pension, holidays, hybrid work, stock options for excellent performance, health insurance option, etc.) - Great perks (free lunch, company events) - Great facilities - Great learning opportunities - Great people - If the center of gravity in German decides that Ireland is undeserving of proper salary increases, which is common, managers can provide high performing employees with stock options that end up paying out quite well after 3 years... but you can't leave otherwise you won't collect... basically a hook to keep you hanging on for that tiny carrot
cons: - No "real" avenues for advancement as Ireland is treated like a sort of indentured servant for Germany - Very low salaries for the high level of work and expectations as you move up the illusionary chain - Intellectually insulting job "titles" that are given to those moving up the illusionary chain that don't actually exist within their HR definitions but make college grads feel good about getting paid so little for their growing expertise, but only insult old dogs with actual industry experience - Struggle to get in-lieu days or overtime payments when forced to work weekends or for more than the 37.5 hour work week (which happens quite frequently) - International clients and a dysfunctional "follow-the-sun" support model due to terrible service from partners in India, China, and South America means that you'll almost always be expected to join customer calls at any time in a 24-hour day, including weekends if clients schedule their builds then. - Poor management communication. It's an IT product business built on the "rush to market" philosophy in order to remain competitive, meaning that from product conception (usually a brain fart by an over paid sales person in the US or Germany) to implementation and everywhere in between, there is little real idea or enough time to fully flesh out the concept, putting the pressure on everyone but the sales team and upper management... (e.g. everyone in Ireland) - If you have work ethic, take pride in your work, and love customer service, it begins to get a little frustrating when you see institutionalized fulltimers that don't pull their weight but get paid practically the same amount as you, even though you're working 2x as hard 2x longer. HR doesn't have the guts to cut off the dead weight once they're part of the system so you're stuck with them. - It's essentially run like an American tech company, a very deliberate revolving door sophisticated attrition system in order to keep average salaries low and avoid employees working their until retirement. It works and it isn't going to change. - Salary bumps are minute and don't reflect inflationary pressures, fiscally translating into a pay cut year on year sometimes (as annual inflation is greater than salary increases) - In my experience, the vast majority of SAP clients had a particular disdain for SAP products and services but felt grandfathered in to using them. You'll spend a lot of time commiserating with them and finding creative ways to make them feel better about the slop they believe they're eating. It can take it's toll.

review_title: Excellent place to start your career
pros:
- SAP Fieldglass gives an excellent opportunity to learn the end to end process of a product company. The processes has been well defined and improvised over the years. If you are planning to start a startup this will be a good learning

- Sky is the limit to explore since you are confined to any particular area. You can access anything and everything to learn. Even thou this product has a legacy code, newer solutions are built on newer technologies and beautifully integrated with the legacy code. 

- More than anything, its very interesting to see the innovative solutions built for the Customers to ease their pain. This is both on functional and technical front. 

- Everyone gets an opportunity to put their point across and these are heard as well. 

- There is no hierarchy as such, everyone is easily accessibly

- Wonderful culture and they believe in sharing. You also get a platform to share your passion ( other than work also) 

- most of the Core Product Team who started the product are still around with 20+ years of experience. This speaks volume of the product and their passion.
cons:
-Work load might be slightly higher, but if you are getting to learn and enjoy then should never be a concern
- People complain about pay, but SAP is a good pay master. Anyway there will always be another company who pays much better than what you would be getting. I believe you should focus of how much you are getting to learn and are you happy after a days work.

cons: SAP used to be a good company, from the employee and product point of view, however, it continues to decline in both areas. 1) Pay – still good overall, however, it comes with a price of high demands, long working hours and negatively impacted work / life balance. 2) Benefits – look god on “paper”, however, in reality hard to utilize. Time off is negatively affected by high demands, learning advancement hard to get as it is linked to manager’s budget / performance, and the rest is similar to other tech companies. 3) Management / company structure – different in various parts, however, overall highly hierarchical and focused on German top management. Company rewards qualities that in many cases lead to promoting “bad” managers. Leadership and vision are negatively affected as many in top positions left the company. The current top management is just supervising the operation. 4) Job security – relatively low if you are outside of EU. German / European employees are unionized and protected by EU law, so any workforce changes only affect those outside of EU. Layoffs often happen behind the scenes. 5) Products / innovation - SAP used to innovate internally, however, for some time the focus has been on just acquiring. The acquisitions had a varying level of success, yet almost none went well. The result is a suite of disjoined products requiring ongoing fixes, corrections and many time re-architecting. Switch to the subscription model shifted the burden of those issues to SAP employees. 6) People - the company has been steadily losing top talent / performers. 6) Other – financials are heavily influenced by outside investors. You can still learn something for your next step; however, plan than next step early.

cons: Speaking solely about their involvement in the healthcare industry for ERP, they haven’t EVER been competitive in this space and have failed to make a commitment to doing so. Selling within the healthcare group is an uphill battle for many reasons but truly are leaders in many other industries.

job_title: Account Executive in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing SMEs and support when you are in a sales cycle. Smart people who are willing to help and share their expertise. If you get a good named account list, you can be successful.
cons: Terrible demand gen organization. You will be on your own for cold calling and prospecting. This is where you lose work life balance! A lot of pressure to build pipeline with no PROPERLY staffed and distributed demand gen support. No account history repository so you start from ground zero when you get your account list, begging the former team for their time on the phone to data dump. MEN get the best accounts compared to tenured women and therefore appear to be more successful in the role and then get promoted as a result. THIS NEEDS TO CHANGE! Sellers are hurt by accounts not renewing software that they purchased years ago that the sales rep had nothing to do with. Sellers are hurt by the cost of providing SAP services to help accounts realize the value of what they bought. For example, if SAP provides a free consultant to assist an account, that cost comes out of the sellers next deal or is carved out of their commission check! If a concession is made and a credit is given to the account, that comes out of the sellers commission! This is demotivating and unfair!

job_title: Senior Product Manager in South San Francisco, CA
pros: In general, reasonable work-life balance. Strong support for full-time remote work, even pre-pandemic. Healthy culture of honest, open communication. Positive collaboration between departments.
cons:
Diversity and inclusion, while good, has sort of gone a little too far like it drives the company. If you are a female wanting to climb the ladder you have a distinct advantage, enjoy it, they will roll out the red carpet for you.

Not always nimble. Process changes were mandated frequently, but change in reality happened slowly, like turning a large ship. Often as soon as everyone finally got on board with the changes, new changes were required.

Sometimes it seemed like changes were mandated simply because a new chief took the reins and felt the need to rock the boat.

In 2019 shortly before the pandemic hit, SAP laid off thousands of people as part of a "global restructuring." In the United States, employees and entire teams getting the axe were told their time was up because they were not co-located. So remote work would no longer be supported? Funny how the new rule did not apply to everyone. Many suspected it was a way to eliminate older, senior, highly compensated employees. Then enter the pandemic -- "Oops, reverse that, we were just kidding, remote work is the only way!"

review_title: Great culture but time to invest on innovation
pros:
SAP has wonderful people. There will always be a few bad apples wherever you go- SAP is no exception. But for the most part, I’ve never worked with a kinder bunch. You are free to share your ideas and be your authentic self. 
Pay is standard market , benefits- standard. Great work life balance- It’s HQ out of Germany encourages employees to take their vacation time and really supports employees well. I have literally never seen any amount of back stabbing or underhandedness from anyone here. Best culture in a company so far.
cons: Equity sharing could be way better. 401k matching is not great. Product portfolio needs to modern up! Large company that trips over its internal processes which makes any change time consuming. Germany doesn’t seem to place the almighty buck in an equivalent importance as US in terms of aggressiveness in sales but their kindness to their people somewhat makes up for that. Everything in life has its trade offs. Quantity or quality… you need to decide.

job_title: Senior Software Developer in Sofia, Sofia (city)
pros:
* steady and stable work environment
* there a lot of good engineers
* good starting place for interns or for people without a lot of experience
cons:
* lower pay compared to other companies on the market
* a lot of internal politics
* bad middle management
* at certain teams there is a lot of favoritism
* very few opportunities for career development
* usually decisions are made for political reasons instead of technical ones, which has a bad impact on the product
* managers love and promote "talkers" instead of "doers"
* depending on the team one can get stuck with legacy tech, making it unemployable in the long term
* a lot of "coasters" and the company is fine with that
* not a lot of work for senior engineers, thus most people leave after a certain number of years
* the higher management does not know what it's doing
* overall, the company is in decline and the higher management has no idea how to improve the situation
* very frequent re-organizations
* after each reorganization everything starts from scratch, thus a  lot of effort is lost for no good reason
